67459.meaning_1: due to doubt; because of uncertainty
67459.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this term explains the cause for the loss of concentration (samādhi), showing how doubt directly affects meditative states.
67459.sutta_1: ‘vicikicchā kho me udapādi, vicikicchādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
67459.example_1: ‘Doubt arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.

26362.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, "samādhi cavi" refers to the falling away or cessation of meditative absorption due to doubt.
26362.sutta_1: ‘vicikicchā kho me udapādi, vicikicchādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
26362.example_1: ‘Doubt arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.

8501.meaning_1: due to lack of attention; because of loss of focus
8501.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this term explains the cause for the loss of samādhi (concentration), showing its practical application in meditation contexts.
8501.sutta_1: ‘amanasikāro kho me udapādi, amanasikārādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
8501.example_1: ‘Loss of focus arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.

31500.meaning_1: due to dullness and drowsiness; because of sloth and torpor
31500.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this term explains the reason for the loss of concentration (samādhi cavi).
31500.sutta_1: ‘thinamiddhaṃ kho me udapādi, thinamiddhādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.

16827.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, ubhatopasse refers to killers springing out from both sides of the road, indicating a situation of being surrounded or attacked from two directions.
16827.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso addhānamaggappaṭipanno, tassa ubhatopasse vaṭṭakā uppateyyuṃ, tassa tatonidānaṃ chambhitattaṃ uppajjeyya;
16827.example_1: Suppose a person was traveling along a road, and killers were to spring out at them from both sides. They’d feel terrified because of that.

16574.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, uppateyyuṃ describes killers suddenly emerging from both sides of the road, hence the meaning "spring out" fits the context.
16574.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso addhānamaggappaṭipanno, tassa ubhatopasse vaṭṭakā uppateyyuṃ, tassa tatonidānaṃ chambhitattaṃ uppajjeyya;
16574.example_1: Suppose a person was traveling along a road, and killers were to spring out at them from both sides. They’d feel terrified because of that.

16683.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, uppila is listed alongside other mental hindrances like doubt and dullness, suggesting it refers to an agitated or overly excited mental state that disrupts meditation.
16683.sutta_1: sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṃ, na chambhitattaṃ, na uppilan’ti.
16683.example_1: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation will arise in me again.’

16754.phonetic:
plu > pilu
dp > bb
ly > ll
16754.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence from MN128, ubbilla refers to a mental state of excitement or elation that disrupts meditation (samādhi). The passage describes how this excitement causes the meditative concentration to fall away.
16754.example_1: so kho ahaṃ, anuruddhā … tassa mayhaṃ, anuruddhā, etadahosi, uppilaṃ [ubbillaṃ, ubbilaṃ] kho me udapādi, uppilādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi. samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.

16753.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, ubbila refers to a mental state of excitement or elation that disrupts meditation, causing the loss of concentration and vision of forms.
16753.example_1: so kho ahaṃ, anuruddhā … tassa mayhaṃ, anuruddhā, etadahosi, uppilaṃ [ubbillaṃ, ubbilaṃ] kho me udapādi, uppilādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi. samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.

16685.meaning_1: due to elation; because of exhilaration
16685.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this term being used to explain the cause of losing meditative concentration (samādhi), indicating it refers to a state of excessive excitement that disrupts mental focus.
16685.sutta_1: ‘uppilaṃ kho me udapādi, uppilādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
16685.example_1: ‘Elation arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.

39815.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this refers to multiple entrances to hidden treasures, suggesting abundant opportunity or discovery.
39815.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso ekaṃ nidhimukhaṃ gavesanto sakideva pañcanidhimukhāni adhigaccheyya, tassa tatonidānaṃ uppilaṃ uppajjeyya;
39815.example_1: Suppose a person was looking for an entrance to a hidden treasure. And all at once they’d come across five entrances! They’d feel excited because of that.

33109.meaning_1: due to heaviness; because of discomfort
33109.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this term explains why the meditative concentration was lost - due to physical discomfort or heaviness.
33109.sutta_1: ‘duṭṭhullaṃ kho me udapādi, duṭṭhullādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.

978.meaning_1: due to overly aroused energy; because of effort too forcefully applied
978.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
This term appears in the context of meditation where excessive effort leads to the loss of concentration (samādhi). It highlights the Buddhist principle of the Middle Way, avoiding extremes in practice.
978.sutta_1: ‘accāraddhavīriyaṃ kho me udapādi, accāraddhavīriyādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
978.example_1: ‘Excessive energy arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.

65798.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows vaṭṭakā refers to a quail being held tightly in hands, matching the meaning found in related entries like vaṭṭaka 1 (masc). The feminine form vaṭṭakā appears to be a variant.
65798.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso ubhohi hatthehi vaṭṭakaṃ gāḷhaṃ gaṇheyya, so tattheva patameyya;
65798.example_1: Suppose a person was to grip a quail too tightly in their hands—it would die right there.

24885.grammar: ind, adv, acc sg of gāḷha
24885.construction:
√gāh + ta > gāḍha > gāḷha + aṃ
gāḷha + aṃ
24885.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, gāḷhaṃ describes the excessive tightness of the grip that would cause the quail to die.
24885.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso ubhohi hatthehi vaṭṭakaṃ gāḷhaṃ gaṇheyya, so tattheva patameyya;
24885.example_1: Suppose a person was to grip a quail too tightly in their hands—it would die right there.

41703.meaning_1: passes out; faints; dies of exhaustion
41703.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, patameyya is used to describe the death of a quail due to being gripped too tightly, illustrating the verb's meaning of dying from exhaustion or external pressure.
41703.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso ubhohi hatthehi vaṭṭakaṃ gāḷhaṃ gaṇheyya, so tattheva patameyya;
41703.example_1: Suppose a person was to grip a quail too tightly in their hands—it would die right there.

50927.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, the variant reading "matameyya" appears as an alternative to "patameyya", suggesting a semantic connection between falling and dying in this context.
50927.example_1: samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ. seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso ubhohi hatthehi vaṭṭakaṃ gāḷhaṃ gaṇheyya, so tattheva patameyya [matameyya (bahūsu) pa + taṃ + eyya = patameyya-iti padavibhāgo], evameva kho me, anuruddhā, accāraddhavīriyaṃ udapādi, accāraddhavīriyādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi. samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.

2317.meaning_1: overly loose energy; weak application of effort
2317.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, atilīnavīriya is contrasted with accāraddhavīriya (excessive energy), showing the middle path between laxity and over-exertion in spiritual practice.
2317.sutta_1: sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṃ, na chambhitattaṃ, na uppilaṃ, na duṭṭhullaṃ, na accāraddhavīriyaṃ, na atilīnavīriyan’ti.
2317.example_1: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort nor excessive energy nor overly lax energy will arise in me again.’

16573.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, uppateyya (optative) refers to a quail flying out of someone's hands when held too loosely, illustrating the basic meaning of sudden upward movement.
16573.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso vaṭṭakaṃ sithilaṃ gaṇheyya, so tassa hatthato uppateyya;
16573.example_1: Suppose a person was to grip a quail too loosely—it would fly out of their hands.

7618.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, abhijappā is described as a defilement (upakkilesa) of the mind (citta), highlighting its negative connotation in this context.
7618.sutta_1: ‘abhijappā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā abhijappaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ,

7620.meaning_1: due to intense longing; because of praying
7620.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this term being used to explain the loss of concentration (samādhi) due to arising longing (abhijappā). The compound follows the tatiyā tappurisa pattern, indicating the cause/reason relationship.
7620.sutta_1: ‘abhijappā kho me udapādi, abhijappādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.

36231.meaning_1: due to the concept of diversity; because of the perception of multiplicity
36231.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this term explains the cause for the loss of concentration (samādhi cavi) due to arising perceptions of diversity (nānattasaññā).
36231.sutta_1: ‘nānattasaññā kho me udapādi, nānattasaññādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.

2180.meaning_1: fact of over-analysing; fact of over-contemplating
2180.construction:
ati + ni + jhāya + ita + tta
atinijjhāyita + tta
2180.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this term describes a state of excessive meditation on forms that leads to loss of concentration, illustrating the danger of over-contemplation in meditation practice.
2180.sutta_1: ‘atinijjhāyitattaṃ kho me rūpānaṃ udapādi, atinijjhāyitattādhikaraṇañca pana me rūpānaṃ samādhi cavi.
2180.example_1: ‘Excessive concentration on forms arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.

2181.meaning_1: due to the fact of over-analysing; because of over-contemplating
2181.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The term describes a cause for losing concentration (samādhi) due to excessive mental engagement with an object, as seen in the contextual sentence from MN128 where over-contemplation of forms leads to the falling away of immersion.
2181.sutta_1: ‘atinijjhāyitattaṃ kho me rūpānaṃ udapādi, atinijjhāyitattādhikaraṇañca pana me rūpānaṃ samādhi cavi.
2181.example_1: ‘Excessive concentration on forms arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.

48288.meaning_1: Discourse on the Fool and the Wise
48288.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The sutta contrasts the behavior and fate of fools (bāla) and the wise (paṇḍita). In the contextual sentence, it is mentioned as the ninth sutta (navamaṃ) in its collection.

48292.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence from MN 129, this term is used to describe the distinguishing marks or characteristics that identify a fool (bāla). The compound clearly shows possession (genitive relationship) where the characteristics belong to the fool.
48292.example_1: “These are the three characteristics, signs, and manifestations of a fool.

48305.meaning_1: characteristic of a fool; manifestation of an idiot
48305.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, bālāpadānāni is used alongside bālalakkhaṇāni and bālanimittāni, suggesting it refers to observable behaviors or traits that characterize a fool.
48305.example_1: “These are the three characteristics, signs, and manifestations of a fool.

33071.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence contrasts the behavior of a fool (bālo) with the threefold poor actions of thinking (duccintitacintī), speaking (dubbhāsitabhāsī), and acting (dukkaṭakammakārī). The compound duccintitacintī emphasizes the negative quality of the thinking process itself.
33071.sutta_1: idha, bhikkhave, bālo duccintitacintī ca hoti dubbhāsitabhāsī ca dukkaṭakammakārī ca.
33071.example_1: A fool thinks poorly, speaks poorly, and acts poorly.

33718.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this describes one of the three characteristics of a fool (bālo), along with poor thinking (duccintitacintī) and poor actions (dukkaṭakammakārī).
33718.sutta_1: idha, bhikkhave, bālo duccintitacintī ca hoti dubbhāsitabhāsī ca dukkaṭakammakārī ca.
33718.example_1: A fool thinks poorly, speaks poorly, and acts poorly.

32853.meaning_lit: doing actions which are badly done
32853.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this describes a fool who engages in poor actions along with poor thinking and speaking.
32853.sutta_1: idha, bhikkhave, bālo duccintitacintī ca hoti dubbhāsitabhāsī ca dukkaṭakammakārī ca.
32853.example_1: A fool thinks poorly, speaks poorly, and acts poorly.

30425.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, tāḷenta describes the action of whipping or beating with various instruments (whips, canes, clubs).
30425.sutta_1: kasāhipi tāḷente vettehipi tāḷente addhadaṇḍakehipi tāḷente hatthampi chindante pādampi chindante hatthapādampi chindante kaṇṇampi chindante nāsampi chindante kaṇṇanāsampi chindante bilaṅgathālikampi karonte saṅkhamuṇḍikampi karonte rāhumukhampi karonte jotimālikampi karonte hatthapajjotikampi karonte erakavattikampi karonte cīrakavāsikampi karonte eṇeyyakampi karonte baḷisamaṃsikampi karonte kahāpaṇikampi karonte khārāpatacchikampi karonte palighaparivattikampi karonte palālapīṭhakampi karonte tattenapi telena osiñcante sunakhehipi khādāpente jīvantampi sūle uttāsente asināpi sīsaṃ chindante.
30425.example_1: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘Rāhu’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the dogs, being impaled alive, and being beheaded.

2994.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, addhadaṇḍakehipi tāḷente refers to being beaten with short sticks or truncheons, indicating it was used as an instrument of punishment.
2994.sutta_1: kasāhipi tāḷente vettehipi tāḷente addhadaṇḍakehipi tāḷente hatthampi chindante pādampi chindante hatthapādampi chindante kaṇṇampi chindante nāsampi chindante kaṇṇanāsampi chindante bilaṅgathālikampi karonte saṅkhamuṇḍikampi karonte rāhumukhampi karonte jotimālikampi karonte hatthapajjotikampi karonte erakavattikampi karonte cīrakavāsikampi karonte eṇeyyakampi karonte baḷisamaṃsikampi karonte kahāpaṇikampi karonte khārāpatacchikampi karonte palighaparivattikampi karonte palālapīṭhakampi karonte tattenapi telena osiñcante sunakhehipi khādāpente jīvantampi sūle uttāsente asināpi sīsaṃ chindante.
2994.example_1: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘Rāhu’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the dogs, being impaled alive, and being beheaded.

23628.meaning_1: making (someone) eat; causing to be eaten (by)
23628.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, "sunakhehipi khādāpente" means "being fed to the dogs", showing the causative sense of making someone/something be eaten by another.
23628.sutta_1: kasāhipi tāḷente vettehipi tāḷente addhadaṇḍakehipi tāḷente hatthampi chindante pādampi chindante hatthapādampi chindante kaṇṇampi chindante nāsampi chindante kaṇṇanāsampi chindante bilaṅgathālikampi karonte saṅkhamuṇḍikampi karonte rāhumukhampi karonte jotimālikampi karonte hatthapajjotikampi karonte erakavattikampi karonte cīrakavāsikampi karonte eṇeyyakampi karonte baḷisamaṃsikampi karonte kahāpaṇikampi karonte khārāpatacchikampi karonte palighaparivattikampi karonte palālapīṭhakampi karonte tattenapi telena osiñcante sunakhehipi khādāpente jīvantampi sūle uttāsente asināpi sīsaṃ chindante.
23628.example_1: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘Rāhu’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the dogs, being impaled alive, and being beheaded.

14803.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, uttāsente describes the act of impaling someone alive on a stake (sūle), showing its transitive nature with both accusative (the person) and locative (the stake) objects.
14803.sutta_1: kasāhipi tāḷente vettehipi tāḷente addhadaṇḍakehipi tāḷente hatthampi chindante pādampi chindante hatthapādampi chindante kaṇṇampi chindante nāsampi chindante kaṇṇanāsampi chindante bilaṅgathālikampi karonte saṅkhamuṇḍikampi karonte rāhumukhampi karonte jotimālikampi karonte hatthapajjotikampi karonte erakavattikampi karonte cīrakavāsikampi karonte eṇeyyakampi karonte baḷisamaṃsikampi karonte kahāpaṇikampi karonte khārāpatacchikampi karonte palighaparivattikampi karonte palālapīṭhakampi karonte tattenapi telena osiñcante sunakhehipi khādāpente jīvantampi sūle uttāsente asināpi sīsaṃ chindante.
14803.example_1: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘Rāhu’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the dogs, being impaled alive, and being beheaded.

46347.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this describes someone physically positioned on a seat (pīṭha), contrasted with being on a bed (mañca) or ground (chamā). The compound suggests active mounting/ascending (samārūḷha) rather than passive sitting.
46347.sutta_1: puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bālaṃ pīṭhasamārūḷhaṃ vā mañcasamārūḷhaṃ vā chamāyaṃ vā semānaṃ, yānissa pubbe pāpakāni kammāni katāni kāyena duccaritāni vācāya duccaritāni manasā duccaritāni tānissa tamhi samaye olambanti ajjholambanti abhippalambanti.
46347.example_1: Furthermore, when a fool is resting on a chair or a bed or on the ground, their past bad deeds—misconduct of body, speech, and mind—settle down upon them, rest down upon them, and lay down upon them.

50783.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this adjective describing a fool resting on a bed, with the past bad deeds weighing upon them.
50783.sutta_1: puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bālaṃ pīṭhasamārūḷhaṃ vā mañcasamārūḷhaṃ vā chamāyaṃ vā semānaṃ, yānissa pubbe pāpakāni kammāni katāni kāyena duccaritāni vācāya duccaritāni manasā duccaritāni tānissa tamhi samaye olambanti ajjholambanti abhippalambanti.
50783.example_1: Furthermore, when a fool is resting on a chair or a bed or on the ground, their past bad deeds—misconduct of body, speech, and mind—settle down upon them, rest down upon them, and lay down upon them.

18910.meaning_1: settles down; rests down; hangs down
18910.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, the verb describes how past bad deeds "settle down" or "rest upon" a person, suggesting a metaphorical hanging or weighing down.
18910.sutta_1: puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bālaṃ pīṭhasamārūḷhaṃ vā mañcasamārūḷhaṃ vā chamāyaṃ vā semānaṃ, yānissa pubbe pāpakāni kammāni katāni kāyena duccaritāni vācāya duccaritāni manasā duccaritāni tānissa tamhi samaye olambanti ajjholambanti abhippalambanti.
18910.example_1: Furthermore, when a fool is resting on a chair or a bed or on the ground, their past bad deeds—misconduct of body, speech, and mind—settle down upon them, rest down upon them, and lay down upon them.

7981.meaning_1: lays down upon; settles down upon
7981.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, abhippalambati describes how past bad deeds "lay down upon" a fool when resting, suggesting a metaphorical weight or burden settling upon them.
7981.sutta_1: puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bālaṃ pīṭhasamārūḷhaṃ vā mañcasamārūḷhaṃ vā chamāyaṃ vā semānaṃ, yānissa pubbe pāpakāni kammāni katāni kāyena duccaritāni vācāya duccaritāni manasā duccaritāni tānissa tamhi samaye olambanti ajjholambanti abhippalambanti.
7981.example_1: Furthermore, when a fool is resting on a chair or a bed or on the ground, their past bad deeds—misconduct of body, speech, and mind—settle down upon them, rest down upon them, and lay down upon them.

57843.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this being used to describe an extreme form of suffering (being struck with 300 spears). The compound follows the digu pattern like other number+noun compounds in the related words.
57843.sutta_1: api nu so puriso tīhi sattisatehi haññamāno tatonidānaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvediyethā”ti?
57843.example_1: Would that man experience pain and distress from being struck with three hundred spears?”

45393.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, pāṇimatto pāsāṇo refers to a stone that is hand-sized, emphasizing its small size compared to the Himalayas.
45393.sutta_1: katamo nu kho mahantataro—yo cāyaṃ mayā paritto pāṇimatto pāsāṇo gahito, yo ca himavā pabbatarājā”ti?
45393.example_1: Which is bigger: the stone the size of my palm that I’ve picked up, or the Himalayas, the king of mountains?”

38000.meaning_1: hellish; god-awful; diabolical; related to hell
38000.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, nirayaka is used to describe the extreme suffering of hell, emphasizing its incomparable nature to worldly pain.
38000.sutta_1: “evameva kho, bhikkhave, yaṃ so puriso tīhi sattisatehi haññamāno tatonidānaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti taṃ nirayakassa dukkhassa upanidhāya saṅkhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti.
38000.example_1: “In the same way, compared to the suffering in hell, the pain and distress experienced by that man due to being struck with three hundred spears doesn’t count, it’s not worth a fraction, there’s no comparison.

39910.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this refers to a specific form of punishment in hell involving five types of binding or crucifixion.
39910.sutta_1: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā pañcavidhabandhanaṃ nāma kammakāraṇaṃ karonti—
39910.example_1: The wardens of hell punish them with the five-fold crucifixion.

8781.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, ayokhīla refers to the iron stakes used as instruments of torture in hell.
8781.example_1: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā pañcavidhabandhanaṃ nāma kammakāraṇaṃ karonti, tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ [ayokhīlaṃ] hatthe gamenti, tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ dutiye hatthe gamenti, tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ pāde gamenti, tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ dutiye pāde gamenti, tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ majjhe urasmiṃ gamenti. so tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti [byantihoti] .

61996.meaning_1: having laid down; having placed down
61996.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, the word describes the action of hell wardens forcefully throwing beings down before hacking them, showing a violent rather than gentle laying down.
61996.sutta_1: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā saṃvesetvā kuṭhārīhi tacchanti.
61996.example_1: The wardens of hell throw them down and hack them with axes. …

29260.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, tacchati is used with instrumental case (kuṭhārīhi) to indicate the tool used for hacking.
29260.sutta_1: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā saṃvesetvā kuṭhārīhi tacchanti.
29260.example_1: The wardens of hell throw them down and hack them with axes. …

803.meaning_1: mountain of burning embers; massive pile of charcoal
803.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this refers to a torture in hell where beings are forced to climb up and down a massive burning coal mountain.
803.sutta_1: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā mahantaṃ aṅgārapabbataṃ ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ āropentipi oropentipi.
803.example_1: They make them climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing. …

12574.meaning_1: makes climb up; forces to ascend
12574.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, āropenti refers to the hell-guardians forcing beings to climb a burning mountain, showing the causative force of the verb.
12574.sutta_1: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā mahantaṃ aṅgārapabbataṃ ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ āropentipi oropentipi.
12574.example_1: They make them climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing. …

18887.meaning_1: makes climb down; forces to descend
18887.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, oropenti is used to describe hell-guardians forcing beings to descend a mountain of burning coals, emphasizing the coercive aspect of the causative meaning.
18887.sutta_1: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā mahantaṃ aṅgārapabbataṃ ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ āropentipi oropentipi.
18887.example_1: They make them climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing. …

56163.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this refers to a red-hot metal pot used as an instrument of torture in hell.
56163.sutta_1: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā uddhampādaṃ adhosiraṃ gahetvā tattāya lohakumbhiyā pakkhipanti ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya.
56163.example_1: The wardens of hell turn them upside down and throw them into a red-hot copper pot, burning, blazing, and glowing.

47820.grammar: ind, adv, comp, acc sg of pheṇuddehaka
47820.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence (MN 129.15.2), it describes how something is cooking with foam bubbling up, illustrating a vivid image of the process.

25863.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, it describes a structure with four corners and four doors, likely referring to a square or rectangular building.
25863.example_1: ‘Four are its corners, four its doors,

8809.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The compound describes a boundary or enclosure fortified with iron, emphasizing strong protection.

8754.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, "ayasā paṭikujjito" refers to a roof made of iron, showing the material sense of the adjective.

38001.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this refers to teachings about the nature and consequences of hell realms in Buddhist cosmology.
38001.sutta_1: anekapariyāyenapi kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayakathaṃ katheyyaṃ;
38001.example_1: I could tell you many different things about hell.

9267.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, "alla" describes fresh grass (allāni tiṇāni) in contrast to dried grass (sukhāni tiṇāni), emphasizing its moist, green state.
9267.sutta_1: te allānipi tiṇāni sukkhānipi tiṇāni dantullehakaṃ khādanti.
9267.example_1: They eat by cropping fresh or dried grass with their teeth.

31918.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this describes how animals eat grass by tearing it with their teeth. The compound is instrumental tappurisa (dantena ullehakaṃ).
31918.sutta_1: te allānipi tiṇāni sukkhānipi tiṇāni dantullehakaṃ khādanti.
31918.example_1: They eat by cropping fresh or dried grass with their teeth.

25176.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
Used in MN 129 to describe animals that feed on dung. The compound clearly shows the characteristic of certain creatures.
25176.example_1: There are animals that feed on dung.

25170.meaning_1: smell of excrement; whiff of dung
25170.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, the word describes the smell that attracts certain beings, illustrating its literal meaning in a vivid context.
25170.example_1: When they catch a whiff of dung they run to it, thinking,

13278.meaning_1: smell of an oblation; whiff of a sacrifice
13278.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, the term refers to the smell of burnt offerings that attracts brahmins, showing its ritual significance.
13278.example_1: It’s like when brahmins smell a burnt offering, they run to it, thinking,

24154.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, gaṇḍuppādā appears alongside kīṭā (moths) and puḷavā (maggots) as creatures born in darkness, suggesting it refers to a type of worm or underground creature.
24154.sutta_1: kīṭā puḷavā gaṇḍuppādā, ye vā panaññepi keci tiracchānagatā pāṇā andhakāre jāyanti andhakāre jīyanti andhakāre mīyanti.
24154.example_1: Moths, maggots, earthworms, and various others.

30757.meaning_1: talk about the animal realm; discussion about animal birth
30757.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
The contextual sentence shows this term refers to discussions about the nature and experiences of beings in the animal realm, one of the lower realms of existence in Buddhist cosmology.
30757.sutta_1: anekapariyāyenapi kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, tiracchānayonikathaṃ katheyyaṃ;
30757.example_1: I could tell you many different things about the animal realm.

66554.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, this term is used to describe an extremely long period of time (a hundred thousand years) in the analogy of the blind turtle.
66554.example_1: tamenaṃ puratthimo vāto pacchimena saṃhareyya, pacchimo vāto puratthimena saṃhareyya, uttaro vāto dakkhiṇena saṃhareyya, dakkhiṇo vāto uttarena saṃhareyya. tatrāssa kāṇo kacchapo, so vassasatassa vassasatassa [vassasatassa vassasahassassa vassasatasahassassa, vassasatassa] accayena sakiṃ ummujjeyya. taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, api nu so kāṇo kacchapo amusmiṃ ekacchiggale yuge gīvaṃ paveseyyāti?

33798.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
Comparative form of dullabha, used in the context to emphasize the extreme rarity of a fool being reborn as a human after falling into the underworld.
33798.sutta_1: “khippataraṃ kho so, bhikkhave, kāṇo kacchapo amusmiṃ ekacchiggale yuge gīvaṃ paveseyya, ato dullabhatarāhaṃ, bhikkhave, manussattaṃ vadāmi sakiṃ vinipātagatena bālena.
33798.example_1: “That one-eyed turtle would poke its neck through the hole in that yoke sooner than a fool who has fallen to the underworld would be reborn as a human being, I say.

23821.comment:
deepseek: deepseek-chat
In the contextual sentence, khujjo describes a physical deformity alongside other terms like kāṇo (blind) and kuṇī (crippled), suggesting a bent or hunched posture.
23821.sutta_1: so ca hoti dubbaṇṇo duddasiko okoṭimako bavhābādho kāṇo vā kuṇī vā khujjo vā pakkhahato vā na lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālāgandhavilepanassa seyyāvasathapadīpeyyassa.
23821.example_1: And they’d be ugly, unsightly, deformed, sickly—one-eyed, crippled, lame, or half-paralyzed. They don’t get to have food, drink, clothes, and vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; or bed, house, and lighting.
